content.question: Suppose a nation opened its borders to the free flow of workers from other nations. How would this event likely affect the long-run aggregate supply <math alttext="open parenthesis, L R A S, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>(LRAS)</mtext></mrow></math> curve and the production possibilities curve of the nation?

choices.label: The <math alttext="open parenthesis, L R A S, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <mtext>LRAS</mtext> </mrow> </math> curve would shift to the right, and the production possibilities curve would not shift.
Both curves would shift to the right.
Both curves would shift to the left.

The <math alttext="open parenthesis, L R A S, close parenthesis" overflow="scroll"> <mrow> <mtext>LRAS</mtext> </mrow> </math> curve would shift to the left, and the production possibilities curve would shift to the right.

content.answer: Both curves would shift to the right.
